body.p: The following topics describe HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard tasks for each dashboard role.

Generally, the privilege hierarchy gives each role all the rights of the roles beneath it. For example, a project administrator can perform all the tasks of a project user, plus some additional tasks. Occasionally, the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard Help provides guidance for best practices that supplement the privilege hierarchy.

section.title: Admin User Tasks
section.p: After your organization works through Getting Started, the Admin user can focus on day-to-day Admin user tasks. As a best practice, the Admin user creates projects and project users, and works on the AdminProject. The Admin user can also change site settings that affect all users, view domains and services, and delete protected images.

Only the Admin user can access the Administration Dashboard Site Settings window. When the Admin user changes site settings, the changes affect all users of the site.

Click Settings in the upper right of any window.

section.title: To Change the Log Level
section.p: Use log level to capture more detailed log files when you need to troubleshoot, or to save disk space with less detailed log files when your system is running routinely.
Log levels are:

li.p: Debug — Writes the most detailed log file messages.
Info — Writes informational, warning, error, and critical messages to the log file.
Warning — Writes warning, error, and critical messages to the log file. Informational messages are not written.
Error — Writes error and critical messages to the log file. Informational and warning messages are not written.
Critical — Writes only critical messages to the log file. Informational, error, and warning messages are not written.

section.p: The default log level is Info. To change the default, select a log level from the drop down list.
To view the Administration Dashboard log file:

li.p: Log into the cloud controller node.
Go to the folder /var/log/skyline, and view the file skyline.log.

section.title: How to Create a Standalone Load Balancer
section.p: You can create a standalone (referenced instance) load balancer and use it to provide load-balancing features for one or more provisioned topologies. Create the load balancer and reference it in your deployment profile.
To create a standalone load balancer:

ol.li: Create an image, if it does not already exist. See How to Create an Image.

Create the resources required for this activity:
Create a keypair, if you do not already have one. See How to Import, Create, or Delete a Keypair.
Use an existing security group, or create a new one that has access to ssh and the load balancer REST service. See How to Create or Delete a Security Group.
IP Protocol From Port To Port Source Access
TCP 22 22 0.0.0.0/0 (CIDR) SSH
TCP 21212 21212 0.0.0.0/0 (CIDR) Load Balancer REST service
Provision a new virtual machine, using the image and resources (above). See How to Launch an Image or Instance Snapshot.
In the Infrastructure > Instances window, find the provisioned load balancer instance and make sure it is in a "Running" power state.
Associate a floating (public) IP address to the provisioned load balancer instance. See How to Associate or Disassociate Floating IPs.

ssh to the provisioned load balancer instance using its floating IP address and the private key (.pem) file. Log in as root.
ssh root@<load balancer's ip address> -i <keypair>.pem
NOTE: If you need to configure a proxy server, you must perform Step 6 before you perform Step 7.

Download two debian packages, haproxy-vm and loadbalancer-api to the provisioned load balancer instance.
wget http://<admin node's public ip address>:8091/ubuntu_dvd/extra/files/loadbalancer/haproxy-vm_1.20.0000_all.deb
wget http://<admin node's public ip address>:8091/ubuntu_dvd/extra/files/loadbalancer/loadbalancer-api_1.20.0000_all.deb
This step requires knowledge of the public IP address for the admin node. Use the ipconfig command to determine the IP address.

If a proxy server is required to access the Internet, make sure the proxy settings are configured on the provisioned load balancer instance.
Modify /etc/bash.bashrc by adding the following two lines. HP recommends that you use IP addresses, because DNS is not always available.
export http_proxy=http://<proxy server ip address>:8080/
export https_proxy=http://<proxy server ip address>:8080/
Modify the sudoers file to ensure the proxy information is available to all programs.
sudo visudo
Add entry: Defaults env_keep += "http_proxy,https_proxy" . (A space character must exist before and after "+=".)
Save the changes.
Log out of the provisioned load balancer instance, and re-connect as root using ssh to set the proxy settings in the environment.

On the provisioned load balancer instance, execute the following commands to install prerequisite software.
apt-get update
apt-get install openjdk-7-jre-headless
apt-get install haproxy
apt-get install tomcat7-user

Install the two debian packages, haproxy-vm and loadbalancer-api on the provisioned load balancer instance.
dpkg -i haproxy-vm_1.20.0000_all.deb
dpkg -i loadbalancer-api_1.20.0000_all.deb
start loadbalancer-api
In a browser, access the URL: http://<load balancer instance's public ip address>:21212/loadbalancer to verify that the load balancer REST service is running.

section.p: Note: After you create a standalone load balancer instance, you can save it as a snapshot. See How to Create an Instance Snapshot.
